tit.cmt: タイトルのため、単語の頭文字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 庸軒流（ようけんりゅう）は、藤村庸軒を流祖と仰ぐ茶道の流派の総称。
sen.e: Yoken-ryu school is a general term for a school of Sado (tea ceremony) in which Yoken FUJIMURA is regarded as the founder.
Yoken-ryu school is the name generally given to a school of Sado (tea ceremony) that regards Yoken FUJIMURA as its founder.
sen.cmt: Without some kind of hint as to what "Sado" means the average native speaker of English would be lost, so thank you for providing a translation.
sen.e: Yoken-ryu school is the name generally given to a school of Sado (tea ceremony) that regards Yoken FUJIMURA as its founder.

sen.j: 初期の伝承系譜によって大きくいくつかの派に分けられるほか、地域ごとに継承の伝統がある。
sen.e: It is largely divided into a number of groups according to the transmission genealogy of the early period; furthermore, each region has its own tradition of succession.

It is largely divided into a number of groups as a result of its teachings being passed on to successive generations of the family during its early days; furthermore, each region has its own tradition of succession.
sen.cmt: Please try to make sure you translate the meaning rather than the words. I find it very difficult to imagine what "transmission genealogy" could possibly mean. I assume it means something like "its teachings being passed on to successive generations of the family" but this will have to be checked.
sen.e: It is largely divided into a number of groups as a result of its teachings being passed on to successive generations of the family during its early days; furthermore, each region has its own tradition of succession.

sen.j: 歴史と系譜
sen.e: History and genealogy
History and genealogy
History and Genealogy
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 藤村庸軒は、久田家初代の久田宗栄の次男で、呉服商十二屋の藤村家に養子に入ったとされる（異説あり）。
sen.e: Yoken FUJIMURA was the second son of Soei HISADA, the first generation of the Hisada family, and he is said to have become an adopted son of the Fujimura family who ran Juniya, a dealer in kimono fabrics.

Yoken FUJIMURA was the second son of Soei HISADA, the ancestor of the Hisada family, and he is said to have been adopted by the Fujimura family, who ran a shop called Juniya that dealt in kimono fabrics.

Yoken FUJIMURA was the second son of Soei HISADA, the ancestor of the Hisada family, and he is said to have been adopted by the Fujimura family, who ran a shop called Juniya that dealt in kimono fabrics.

sen.j: 千宗旦のもとで皆伝を受け宗旦四天王の一人に数えられた。
sen.e: Having obtained full proficiency under SEN no Sotan, Yoken was considered one of the big four of Sotan.
Having become fully proficient in the tea ceremony under the tutelage of SEN no Sotan, Yoken was considered to have been one of Sotan's four best students.
sen.cmt: I doubt a native speaker of English would know that SEN no Sotan is a person so if you can add a hint (such as "under the tutelage of"), it would help the reader a lot. I also think the meaning of "one of the big four of Sotan" is unclear.
sen.e: Having become fully proficient in the tea ceremony under the tutelage of SEN no Sotan, Yoken was considered to have been one of Sotan's four best students.

sen.j: 藤村庸軒の門人には茶に優れた人が多く、それぞれの系譜が伝わっている。
sen.e: Monjin (pupils) of Yoken FUJIMURA includes many who are distinguished in tea preparation, and their genealogies have been passed down, respectively.
Monjin (pupils) of Yoken FUJIMURA include many who are distinguished in tea preparation, and their genealogies have been passed down, respectively.
Monjin (pupils) of Yoken FUJIMURA include many who are distinguished in tea preparation, and their genealogies have been passed down, respectively.

sen.j: そのうち現在まで伝わっているのが藤村正員、近藤柳可、比喜多宗積の流れである。
sen.e: Of those, the styles by Shoin FUJIMURA, Ryuka KONDO, and Soseki HIKATA are still present today.
Of those, the styles by Shoin FUJIMURA, Ryuka KONDO, and Soseki HIKATA are still present today.
Of those, the styles by Seiin FUJIMURA, Ryuka KONDO, and Soseki HIKITA are still present today.
sen.cmt: Shoin FUJIMURA→Seiin FUJIMURAに修正 (参照: http://kotobank.jp/word/%E8%97%A4%E6%9D%91%E6%AD%A3%E5%93%A1)、およびSoseki HIKATA→Soseki HIKITAとしました。

sen.j: 藤村家の本家十二屋は庸軒長男の恕堅から、途中養子を取りながら継承されたが、茶の系譜としては恕堅と松軒のみで絶えている。
sen.e: The original Juniya of the Fujimura family was succeeded by Joken, the first son of Yoken, and continued by employing adoption along the way, but the genealogy of tea preparation came to an end with only Joken and Shoken.

The original Juniya of the Fujimura family was succeeded by Joken, the first son of Yoken, and continued by employing adoption along the way, but the genealogy of tea preparation came to an end with only Joken and Shoken.

The original Juniya of the Fujimura family was succeeded by Joken, the first son of Yoken, and continued by employing adoption along the way, but the genealogy of tea preparation came to an end with only Joken and Shoken.

sen.j: 藤村家（十二屋）歴代
sen.e: Successive heads of the Fujimura family (Juniya)
Successive heads of the Fujimura family (Juniya)
Successive Heads of the Fujimura Family (Juniya)
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 藤村正員の流れ
sen.e: Style by Shoin FUJIMURA
Style by Shoin FUJIMURA
Style by Shoin FUJIMURA

sen.j: 藤村正員は庸軒の次男で、大阪の関東屋の養子となった。
sen.e: Born as the second son of Yoken, Shoin FUJIMURA became an adopted son of Kantoya, a tea dealer in Osaka.
Born as the second son of Yoken, Shoin FUJIMURA became an adopted son of Kantoya, a tea dealer in Osaka.
Born as the second son of Yoken, Shoin FUJIMURA became an adopted son of Kantoya, a tea dealer in Osaka.

sen.j: 正員は一生のあいだ病身であったため、茶道のみを楽しみに暮らしていたとされる。
sen.e: As Shoin was in poor health throughout his life, it is said that Sado became his sole entertainment.
As Shoin was in poor health throughout his life, it is said that Sado became his sole entertainment.
As Shoin was in poor health throughout his life, it is said that Sado became his sole entertainment.

sen.j: 関東屋は庸軒の叔父の藤村紹和を元祖とする縁戚であり、養子による継承を重ねて正斎のあと一時断絶したがのちに再興した。
sen.e: Kantoya was ran by Yoken's relatives, its originator being Tsugukazu FUJIMURA, Yoken's uncle; Kantoya was temporarily discontinued after Seisai in spite of successions by adopted sons, but it was later restored.
sen.cmt: 「関東屋は庸軒の叔父の藤村紹和を元祖とする縁戚であり」だと文章として不十分なので、「関東屋は庸軒の叔父の藤村紹和を元祖とする縁戚により経営され」に修正しました。
sen.e: Kantoya was ran by Yoken's relatives, its originator being Tsugukazu FUJIMURA, Yoken's uncle; Kantoya was temporarily discontinued after Seisai in spite of successions by adopted sons, but it was later restored.

Kantoya was ran by Yoken's relatives, its originator being Tsugukazu FUJIMURA, Yoken's uncle; Kantoya was temporarily discontinued after Seisai in spite of successions by adopted sons, but it was later restored.

sen.j: 藤村正斎のあと茶道は明福寺住職の観山によって盛り立てられ、中興と称されている。
sen.e: After Seisai FUJIMURA, the Sado was supported by Kanzan, a chief priest of Myofuku-ji temple, and is thus regarded as a restored art.
After Seisai FUJIMURA, Sado was supported by Kanzan, a chief priest of Myofuku-ji temple, and is thus regarded as a restored art.
After Seisai FUJIMURA, Sado was supported by Kanzan, a chief priest of Myofuku-ji temple, and is thus regarded as a restored art.

sen.j: この系譜は藤村正員派と呼ばれており、現在は京都で伝承されている。
sen.e: This genealogy is called Shoin FUJIMURA-ha group, and today this tradition is carried on in Kyoto.
This genealogy is called Shoin FUJIMURA-ha group, and today this tradition is carried on in Kyoto.
This genealogy is called Shoin FUJIMURA-ha group, and today this tradition is carried on in Kyoto.

sen.j: 藤村正員の門人に斎藤道節（1684年～1766年）という人があり、元は大阪の人だがのちに江戸で庸軒流を広めた。
sen.e: Monjin (pupils) of Shoin FUJIMURA includes Dosetsu SAITO (1684 - 1766), who was originally from Osaka but later introduced Yoken-ryu school in Edo (present-day Tokyo).
Monjin (pupils) of Shoin FUJIMURA includes Dosetsu SAITO (1684 - 1766), who was originally from Osaka but later introduced the Yoken-ryu school in Edo (present-day Tokyo).
Monjin of Shoin FUJIMURA includes Dosetsu SAITO (1684 - 1766), who was originally from Osaka but later introduced the Yoken-ryu school in Edo (present-day Tokyo).

sen.j: この系譜が庸軒流華道とともに東京で伝わっていたが、茶道については昭和初期に絶えた。
sen.e: Although this genealogy was introduced in Tokyo along with Kado (flower arrangement) of Yoken-ryu school, Sado died out in the early Showa period.
Although this genealogy was introduced in Tokyo along with Kado (flower arrangement) of Yoken-ryu school, Sado died out during the early Showa period.
Although this genealogy was introduced in Tokyo along with Kado (flower arrangement) of Yoken-ryu school, Sado died out during the early Showa period.

sen.j: 藤村正員派
sen.e: Shoin FUJIMURA-ha group
Shoin FUJIMURA-ha group
Shoin FUJIMURA-ha Group
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 近藤柳可の流れ
sen.e: Style by Ryuka KONDO
Style by Ryuka KONDO
Style by Ryuka KONDO

sen.j: 近藤柳可は津藩藤堂氏の依頼により津に赴き茶頭を勤めた人で、以来近藤家は代々藤堂家において指南役を務めてきた。
sen.e: Ryuka KONDO went to Tsu at the request of the Todo clan of the domain of Tsu to serve as a saju/chato (priest in charge of tea ceremony in Zen temple); for generations afterwards, the Kondo family played the role of a coach in the Todo family.

Ryuka KONDO went to Tsu at the request of the Todo clan of the domain of Tsu to serve as a saju/chato (priest in charge of tea ceremony in Zen temple); for generations afterwards, the Kondo family played the role of a coach in the Todo family.

Ryuka KONDO went to Tsu at the request of the Todo clan of the domain of Tsu to serve as a saju (priest in charge of tea ceremony in Zen temple); for generations afterwards, the Kondo family played the role of a coach in the Todo family.
sen.cmt: saju / chato→sajuのみとしました。(参照: http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/76410/m0u/%E8%8C%B6%E9%A0%AD/)

sen.j: 近藤家の8代柳可の後は、津の河野宗通と東京の村口無庵の系譜に分かれ、さらに東京で菅森夢菴の系譜がわかれて現在3系統が伝わっている。
sen.e: After Ryuka, the eighth head of the Kondo family, the genealogy divided into Sotsu KONO in Tsu and Muan MURAGUCHI in Tokyo, and further into Muan SUGAMORI in Tokyo; thus there are three genealogies today.

After Ryuka, the eighth head of the Kondo family, the genealogy divided into Sotsu KONO in Tsu and Muan MURAGUCHI in Tokyo, and further into Muan SUGAMORI in Tokyo; thus there are three genealogies today.

After Ryuka, the eighth head of the Kondo family, the genealogy divided into Sotsu KONO in Tsu and Muan MURAGUCHI in Tokyo, and further into Muan SUGAMORI in Tokyo; thus there are three genealogies today.

sen.j: これらをまとめて近藤柳可派と称している。
sen.e: These three genealogies are collectively called Ryuka KONDO-ha group.
These three genealogies are collectively called the Ryuka KONDO-ha group.
These three genealogies are collectively called the Ryuka KONDO-ha group.

sen.j: 近藤柳可派
sen.e: Ryuka KONDO-ha group
Ryuka KONDO-ha group
Ryuka KONDO-ha Group
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 比喜多宗積の流れ
sen.e: Style by Soseki HIKITA
Style by Soseki HIKITA
Style by Soseki HIKITA

sen.j: 比喜多宗積は屋号を大文字屋という京都の豪商で、日野肩衝を始めとする名物を所蔵していたことでも知られる。
sen.e: Soseki HIKITA was a wealthy merchant who operated Daimonjiya in Kyoto, and he is also known to have owned famous products such as Hino Katatsuki (fine tea container).
Soseki HIKITA was a wealthy merchant who operated Daimonjiya in Kyoto, and he is also known to have owned famous products such as Hino Katatsuki (fine tea container).
Soseki HIKITA was a wealthy merchant who operated Daimonjiya in Kyoto, and he is also known to have owned famous products such as Hino Katatsuki (fine tea container).

sen.j: 5代中田疎軒は近江国堅田の辻氏から養子になった人で、多くの門人があり幕末の京都茶道界で一世を風靡した。
sen.e: The fifth head, Soken NAKATA, was an adopted son who came from the Tsuji clan of Katata, Omi Province, and as he had many Monjin he dominated the tea ceremony community of Kyoto at the end of the Edo period.

The fifth head, Soken NAKATA, was an adopted son who came from the Tsuji clan of Katata, Omi Province, and as he had many Monjin he dominated the tea ceremony community of Kyoto at the end of the Edo period.

The fifth head, Soken NAKATA, was an adopted son who came from the Tsuji clan of Katata, Omi Province, and as he had many Monjin he dominated the tea ceremony community of Kyoto at the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 7代月山は妙心寺537世で桂春院に住し、石河中軒・長谷川諦観・幽玄庵道契といった門弟を育てた。
sen.e: The seventh head, Gassan, resided in Keishun-in as the five-hundred thirty-seventh sei (chief priest) of Myoshin-ji Temple, and his Montei (disciples) included Chuken ISHIKAWA, Taikan HASEGAWA, and Dokei UGENAN.

The seventh head, Gassan, resided in Keishun-in as the five-hundred thirty-seventh sei (chief priest) of Myoshin-ji Temple, and his Montei (disciples) included Chuken ISHIKAWA, Taikan HASEGAWA, and Dokei UGENAN.

The seventh head, Gassan, resided in Keishun-in as the five-hundred thirty-seventh chief priest of Myoshin-ji Temple, and his Montei (disciples) included Chuken ISHIKAWA, Taikan HASEGAWA, and Dokei YUGENAN.
sen.cmt: the five-hundred thirty-seventh sei (chief priest)→the five-hundred thirty-seventh chief priestとし、Dokei UGENAN→Dokei YUGENANに修正

sen.j: これによってそれぞれの系譜に分かれたが、これらをまとめて比喜多宗積派と称している。
sen.e: As such, the Montei separated into respective genealogies, but these genealogies are collectively called the Soseki HIKITA-ha group.
As such, the Montei separated into respective genealogies, but these genealogies are collectively called the Soseki HIKITA-ha group.
As such, the Montei separated into respective genealogies, but these genealogies are collectively called the Soseki HIKITA-ha group.

sen.j: 比喜多宗積派
sen.e: Soseki HIKITA-ha group
Soseki HIKITA-ha group
Soseki HIKITA-ha Group
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: その他
sen.e: Other matters
Other matters
Other Matters
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 北村祐庵（1650年～1719年）は近江国堅田の豪農で、会席料理と造庭に通じ、幽庵焼きなどにその名を残している。
sen.e: Yuan KITAMURA (1650 - 1719) was a wealthy farmer of Katata, Omi Province and was conversant in kaiseki-ryori (set of dishes served on an individual tray for entertaining guests) and landscape gardening, and he left a name in Yuan Yaki (Japanese grill, using meat or fish which are marinated, impaled on long skewers and broiled over hot coals), among other things.

Yuan KITAMURA (1650 - 1719) was a wealthy farmer of Katata, Omi Province and was conversant in kaiseki-ryori (set of dishes served on an individual tray for entertaining guests) and landscape gardening, and he left a name in Yuan Yaki (Japanese grill, using meat or fish which are marinated, impaled on long skewers and broiled over hot coals), among other things.

Yuan KITAMURA (1650 - 1719) was a wealthy farmer of Katata, Omi Province and was conversant in kaiseki-ryori (set of dishes served on an individual tray for entertaining guests) and landscape gardening, and he left a name in Yuan Yaki (Japanese grill, using meat or fish which are marinated, impaled on long skewers and broiled over hot coals), among other things.

sen.j: 北村家代々で伝承していたが、1913年に9代にあたる辻紹久が没して絶えた。
sen.e: Although the tradition was succeeded by the Kitamura family for generations, the family line failed in 1913 with the death of the ninth head, Tsuguhisa TSUJI.
Although the tradition was succeeded by the Kitamura family for generations, the family line failed in 1913 with the death of the ninth head, Tsuguhisa TSUJI.
Although the tradition was succeeded by the Kitamura family for generations, the family line failed in 1913 with the death of the ninth head, Tsuguhisa TSUJI.

sen.j: 山本退庵もまた近江国堅田の人で、米川流香道にも通じていた。
sen.e: Taian YAMAMOTO was also from Katata, Omi Province, and he was conversant in Yonekawa-ryu school of Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony).
Taian YAMAMOTO was also from Katata, Omi Province, and he was conversant in the Yonekawa-ryu school of Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony).
Taian YAMAMOTO was also from Katata, Omi Province, and he was conversant in the Yonekawa-ryu school of Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony).

sen.j: 茶の系譜としては京都西洞院通の矢倉家に伝えられて代々伝承してきたが明治になって絶えた。
sen.e: The genealogy of tea preparation was passed down by the Yagura family of the Nishinotoin-dori street, Kyoto, and was traditionally succeeded for generations, but it died out in the Meiji period.
The genealogy of tea preparation was passed down by the Yagura family of the Nishinotoin-dori street, Kyoto, and was traditionally succeeded for generations, but it died out during the Meiji period.
The genealogy of tea preparation was passed down by the Yagura family of the Nishinotoin-dori Street, Kyoto, and was traditionally succeeded for generations, but it died out during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: streetの頭文字を大文字に修正

sen.j: 横井等甫（1639年～1725年）は京都中立売通の豪商で、米川流香道にも通じていた。
sen.e: Toho YOKOI (1639 - 1725) was a wealthy merchant in Nakadacyuri-dori street, Kyoto, and he was also conversant in Yonekawa-ryu school of Kodo.
Toho YOKOI (1639 - 1725) was a wealthy merchant in Nakadacyuri-dori street, Kyoto, and he was also conversant in the Yonekawa-ryu school of Kodo.
Toho YOKOI (1639 - 1725) was a wealthy merchant in Nakadachiuri-dori Street, Kyoto, and he was also conversant in the Yonekawa-ryu school of Kodo.

sen.j: その後、久保又夢、久保可隆、中村範寿と伝えられているが、幕末を待たずに絶えていると考えられる。
sen.e: The genealogy is said to have been passed down to Matamu KUBO, Yoshitaka KUBO, and Norikazu NAKAMURA, but it is considered to have died out before the end of the Edo period.
The genealogy is said to have been passed down to Matamu KUBO, Yoshitaka KUBO, and Norikazu NAKAMURA, but it is considered to have died out before the end of the Edo period.
The genealogy is said to have been passed down to Matamu KUBO, Yoshitaka KUBO, and Norikazu NAKAMURA, but it is considered to have died out before the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 久須美疎安（1636年～1728年）は京都の人で、藤村庸軒の婿である。
sen.e: Soan KUSUMI (1636 - 1728) was from Kyoto and was a son-in-law of Yoken FUJIMURA.
Soan KUSUMI (1636 - 1728) was from Kyoto and was a son-in-law of Yoken FUJIMURA.
Soan KUSUMI (1636 - 1728) was from Kyoto and was a son-in-law of Yoken FUJIMURA.

sen.j: 『茶話指月集』の著者として有名であり、はじめは千宗旦の門人であったことから、宗旦四天王の一人に数えられることもある。
sen.e: He was famous as the author of Sawa Shigetsu shu (tea ceremony book), and as he was a pupil of SEN no Sotan in the beginning, he is sometimes counted as one of the big four of Sotan.
He was famous as the author of Sawa Shigetsu shu (tea ceremony book), and as he was a pupil of SEN no Sotan in the beginning, he is sometimes counted as one of the big four of Sotan.
He was famous as the author of "Sawa Shigetsu Shu" (tea ceremony book), and as he was a pupil of SEN no Sotan in the beginning, he is sometimes counted as one of Sotan's four best students.
sen.cmt: Sawa Shigetsu Shuとし、クォーテーション追加、前出の表記に合わせ、one of the big four of Sotan→one of Sotan's four best studentsとしました。
